THE SCHOOL ADMINISTRATOR
Page Seven
NEA Sets Up Radio-TV Branch in New York
The National Education Association in
July set up a permanent TV-radio branch
i office in New York City as the first major
move in expanding its public relations serv¬
ices to members. Richard Krolik, recently
with NBC’s Wide, Wide World and Today,
and former director of TV activities for
Life magazine, heads the new office.
Establishment of the TV-radio branch to
maintain liaison with network officials and
producers is a step in NEA’s expanded serv¬
ice program adopted at the Centennial Con¬
vention in Philadelphia. More than 1,200,000
educators will give their active support to
“quality programming in the public inter¬
est” on commercial TV and radio, predicts
EA Executive Secretary William G. Carr.
The new TV-radio office will cooperate
with producers in presenting aspects of edu¬
cation on their programs. Research facilities
of NEA’s Washington headquarters will be
available for shows that will deal with
schools, teachers, the needs of children and
youth, and allied topics.
An example of the type of programming
that can stem from NEA cooperation with
the networks is the “Back to School” salute
to be aired on Monitor, the morn-to-mid-
night NBC radio show, September 6-7-8. In
the biggest sustained salute to America’s
30 million school children ever to hit the
air waves, the show will devote a solid week¬
end to “Back-to-School” news, interviews,
features, and special events.
Note to AASA members: When you or
your staff like what you see or hear over
radio or television—particularly when you
find such programs useful in regular class¬
room work or discussion—let your local sta¬
tion, the network, or the sponsor hear from
you. You will get more station managers
and more sponsors thinking seriously about
top-quality public service programming.
Report of Studies
In School Administration
Mailed to AASA Members
A new book by Hollis A. Moore, Jr., en¬
titled Studies in School Administration, has
been published by the AASA Committee for
the Advancement of School Administration.
Its two purposes are, first, to summarize
major accomplishments in the improvement
of school administration which can be traced
to the Cooperative Program in Educational
Administration (CPEA) ; second, to bring
into one volume an annotated bibliography
of all important publications issued by re¬
gional CPEA centers or by other cooperat¬
ing groups and institutions.
The 202-page book was mailed to AASA
members in July. Copies were distributed
also to_colleges and universities offering
programs in educational administration, as
well as to many professors of education.
Additional copies may be ordered from
AASA (clothbound $3.00, paper $2.50).
Other Reports Recently
Sent to AASA Members
Back to School, a “New from NEA” spe¬
cial bulletin of ideas to help you capitalize
on your community’s interest in back-to-
school month. Adaptable for local use with
newspapers, radio stations, and television
outlets.
TV-Radiogram, to alert you to radio and
television programs beginning September 1

Both these reports were prepared and dis¬

California Administrators
Do Intensive Summer Study
Teachers are not alone in pursuing sum¬
mer courses and other activities to improve
their competencies; school administrators
also are concerned with their own improve¬
ment through inservice education. This is
the opinion of C. C. Trillingham, AASA
president-elect and superintendent of Los
Angeles (Calif.) County schools, whose of¬
fice sponsored a workshop in the Los Nietos
School District, July 15-19, for more than
100 superintendents and principals in school
districts of Los Angeles County. Joint spon¬
sor was the Los Angeles County School Ad¬
ministrators and Supervisors Association.
Dean Irving R. Melbo of the school of
education, USC, spoke on “The Adminis¬
trator’s Responsibilities in Relation to the
Instructional Program.” Other topics in¬
cluded home-school relationships, supervi¬
sion of instruction, effective curriculum
practices, and staff relationships.
Later in the month, at Stanford Univer¬
sity, over 100 school superintendents at¬
tended the first school administrators clinic
in a series planned by the California Asso¬
ciation of School Administrators and uni¬
versities in the state. It was held July 29
to August 2, under the chairmanship of
Professor William R. Odell of the Stan¬
ford School of Education. Instructional im¬
provement, effective community procedures,
planning school buildings, development of
administrative personnel, and school staff
and community morale were studied.
LATE FLASH: Watch for the September
21 issue of The Saturday Evening Post (on
the newsstands Sept. 17) with two articles
answering the question, “Are the Public
Schools Doing Their Job?”
“No,” says John Keats, a free-lance
writer who is sending his three children
to a private school this fall.
“Yes,” declares Herbert L. Brown, Jr.,
managing editor of Changing Times, and
father of two: “The American public-school
system is demonstrating a notable superior¬
ity over private schools.”
